text.p: Malawi's Central Bank on Friday devalued its currency after increased demands for foreign exchange.

"The bank is realigning the kwacha in response to the movements of the currencies of its major trading partners, particularly South Africa and Zimbabwe," the radio said, quoting a central bank statement. "As a result the kwacha exchange rate has depreciated during the last two days."
It added that the measures were necessary as demand for foreign exchange was unsustainable.
The bank accused the business community and the general public of "irresponsibly utilising" the country's scarce foreign exchange by importing commodities that were locally available.
The radio said the bank's move was aimed at rationalising its foreign exchange reserves, which were $130 million in April, compared with $142 million the previous month.
The kwacha fell on Friday to 16.01 from 15.05 kwacha against the dollar on Thursday.
The country's biggest foreign exchange earner is tobacco, which earned Malawi $250 million in 1994.
